body:
It is easy enough to make rclone co-operate with logrotate - it just needs to reopen the log file when it changes.

I've made a prototype of that.

It occurs to me that this won't work on Windows though.

I could instead (or maybe as well) integrate a package like https://github.com/natefinch/lumberjack which does log rotation from within rclone.

That would work well for all platforms.

What do you think?  Do you have a preference?
Hello Nick, my humble opinion: I think an integrated solution would be great!
IMHO - logrotate is the defacto standard in a linux server environment. :)

> IMHO - logrotate is the defacto standard in a linux server environment. :)

Sure, but an integrated solution would work in all environments  ;-)
I concur with @seuffert, so I would prefer logrotate, but anything goes. :)

An integrated solution could use https://github.com/natefinch/lumberjack - I use it in Caddy and it has worked _very_ well. (Edit: I see that Nick has already suggested it! Don't mind me. Count this as a +1 from a happy lumberjack user.)

I've used logrotate with rclone for months without problems. My logrotate.d conf on debian is as follows:

/path/to/rclone.log {
        daily
        rotate 7
        compress
        delaycompress
        missingok
        notifempty
        create 644 crachel crachel
}

other linux distros (ubuntu) may want you to append "su" as the last directive.

ownership on the rclone*.log files needs to be the same user that is executing rclone.  And your rclone command obviously needs to point the --log-file flag at /path/to/rclone.log
@crachel Are you sure this works "in backup"? If rclone finish in between it works fine, but if you "change out" the log-file mid-backup it does not afaik.
Sorry, I understand what the problem is now. Perhaps the logrotate directive "copytruncate" is what you need

Yes, that could actually work. I'm gonna test it.

> copytruncate
> Truncate the original log file to zero size in place after creating a copy, instead of moving the old log file and optionally creating a new one. It can be used when some program cannot be told to close its logfile and thus might continue writing (appending) to the previous log file forever. Note that there is a very small time slice between copying the file and truncating it, so some logging data might be lost. When this option is used, the create option will have no effect, as the old log file stays in place.

Recent rclones open the log file in append mode so copytruncate should work I would have thought.

Assuming that does work the what we should do is document that!

I still like the builtin rotation idea too though so maybe we should do that as well.

I can report back that logrotate does not work with copytruncate for me. It creates a file but it's empty. And it seems that rclone keeps writing to the old one.

This could be an issue with me storing everything on a NFS mount, but even when setting permissions in the logrotate config does not change it.

Has anyone else tested?

@NoLooseEnds I tried this locally and adding `copytruncate` worked perfectly.  logrotate is extremely fussy - run it manually with `logrotate -v --force /path/to/logrotate.conf` and you'll have some idea of what it is doing.

Thanks for confirming that it works!

I solved my issue, it had to do with the NFS permissions (I still don't understand why that should be a problem, but that's another story)

Anyhow, I ended up using the `su <user> <group>` in the logrotate config to run logrotate as a specific user, and that worked.

Final logrotate config:

```
/path/to/logfile.log {
  su <user> <group>
  rotate 7
  copytruncate
  daily
  compress
  missingok
  notifempty
}
```

I guess we can close this, unless you still think it's worth to implement it natively in rclone?

I've put a note in the docs about the `copytruncate` option for `--log-file`.

I think I'll leave this ticket open to implement an integrated solution.
